title: Ratshausen
text:
Ratshausen is a municipality the <a href="Zollernalbkreis">Zollernalbkreis</a> district, in <a href="Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg">Baden-Württemberg</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>.
History.
In 1805, Ratshausen, previously a possession of the Austrian <a href="County%20of%20Hohenberg">County of Hohenberg</a>, was annexed by the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20W%C3%BCrttemberg">Kingdom of Württemberg</a>. Ratshausen was assigned to , and remained in that district until it was dissolved into in 1938. The town transformed after <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> from a rural and agricultural town to a commercial center. Residential space was added to the southwest in the 1950s. As part of the , the district of Balingen was dissolved and Ratshausen reassigned to the newly-created <a href="Zollernalbkreis">district of Zollernalb</a>. Further development took place in the 1990s in the north and south.
Geography.
The municipality ("<a href="Municipalities%20of%20Germany">Gemeinde</a>") of Ratshausen is located in the <a href="Zollernalbkreis">Zollernalb district</a> of <a href="Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg">Baden-Württemberg</a>, one of the 16 <a href="States%20of%20Germany">states</a> of the <a href="Federal%20Republic%20of%20Germany">Federal Republic of Germany</a>. It is located at the southwest end of the district and borders <a href="Tuttlingen%20%28district%29">Tuttlingen district</a> to the south. Ratshausen is physically located primarily in the , in the valley of the <a href="Schlichem">Schlichem</a>, which flows through Ratshausen itself. Elevation above sea level in the municipal area ranges from a high of <a href="Normalnull">Normalnull</a> (NN) at the top of the <a href="Plettenberg%20%28mountain%29">Plettenberg</a> to a low of NN on the Schlichem.
A portion of the Federally-protected <a href="Ortenberg%20%28mountain%29">Ortenberg</a>, , and <a href="Naturschutzgebiet">nature reserves</a> is located in Ratshausen's municipal area.
Coat of arms.
Ratshausen's coat of arms depicts a <a href="Argent">white</a> trowel upon a <a href="Field%20%28heraldry%29">field</a> of <a href="Gules">red</a>. This pattern is derived from a <a href="Seal%20%28emblem%29">seal</a> used in the 19th century by the local <a href="Schulthei%C3%9F">Schultheiß</a> that portrayed a oval shield with a wreath and a trowel upon it. The tool itself is a reference to the compulsory labor inhabitants of Ratshausen were expected to perform in the summer, usually the laying of bricks. The <a href="Tincture%20%28heraldry%29">tincture</a>, a reference to the County of Hohenberg, was decided by the provisional post-WWII <a href="W%C3%BCrttemberg-Hohenzollern">Württemberg-Hohenzollern</a> government that awarded this coat of arms to Ratshausen on 27 March 1950. A corresponding flag was issued by the Zollernalb district office on 21 May 1991.
Transportation.
Local public transportation is provided by the .
